title: Will it remain a mystery how Fermat originally managed to prove his Last Theorem? - Quora

response.answer_text: One thing you need to realize is that while all those new fields were required to be discovered before FLT could be proved through andrew wiles's proof, that doesn't mean that a proof is not possible without them. It's possible that somebody in the future may yet come up with a simpler proof (Very unlikely however). Fermat might have had a proof (Atleast, he probably thought he did). History is rife with incorrect proofs for FLT. It's possible that he had some basic proof in his head (Which was very likely wrong), and if he never even bothered to write it down, it's fair to say he never really analyzed the proof properly. Remember, FLT was only important because it turned out to be so hard to prove, and required so many new discoveries. If Fermat thought he had a (probably incorrect) proof already, he may have thought that the result, while interesting, is not worth going into depth for (And so, without sharing the result or the proof with other mathematicians, he may have never found the error in his proof).

“All is fair in love, war, and in mathematics.” — E. T. Bell. Of course, the great French mathematician and jurist, Pierre de Fermat, was right! But the truth is not publicized unfortunately for political reasons I believe. FLT Reference links: Do Simple Proofs of Fermat's Last Theorem Already Exist? If so, why aren't they popularized?
